ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 2008 TO 31ST MARCH, 2009


(Paper Cmd. 2 of 2008)


     Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [2nd Allotted Day].

 

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

 

     Head P - Ministry of Home Affairs

 

     The Chairman:  Head P - Ministry of Home Affairs.  Dr Teo Ho Pin.

   

 

Terrorism and Security

 

     Dr Teo Ho Pin (Bukit Panjang):  Sir, I beg to move,

 

     That the total sum to be allocated for Head P of the Estimates be reduced by $100.

 

     Sir, I am indeed very surprised to learn that JI leader Mas Selamat, a limping detainee, can escape from our detention centre yesterday.  This has indeed raised concerns about our Police Force vigilance and security operating procedures.

 

     Sir, may I ask the Minister what level of security was imposed on Mas Selamat while in detention?  How did he manage to escape from the detention centre?  What is the status in the manhunt for Mas

Selamat?  Will the Police be conducting a Board of Inquiry into the incident and report to this House the findings of the inquiry?

 

     As Mas Selamat is still at large, it has raised public concerns on their safety.  What is the Police's advice to the general public at this point of time?

 

     Sir, Mas Selamat escaped at 4.05 pm yesterday.  I received news of his escape through Channel NewsAsia and SMS alert at 8.42 pm.  May I know why the Ministry took so long, four hours, to

Column: 1126

inform the public?  Mas Selamat is unarmed, unlike Dave Teo's case.  So why can we not involve the public to help to arrest him?

 

     Sir, the recent arrest of three self-radicalised potential terrorists had shown that terrorism threats are real in Singapore.   Despite much efforts by the authorities and various stakeholders, three young educated Singaporeans can be influenced to wage militant jihad.  The easy access to radical teaching, religious teachings through the Internet over 6,000 radical websites and a large proportion of Singapore's Muslim youth, about 40%, who do not have formal religious instructions pose major concerns to the security of Singapore.

 

     Sir, we should not take comfort that self-radicalised individuals are inevitable, and let our guards down in strengthening our vigilance in particular our efforts to engage the community.  We should set up more vigilance, self-radicalised terrorism watch groups among family members, religious organisations and the community.  I propose that the Ministry develop a simple checklist for community stakeholders to detect individuals who have radical religious beliefs and are potential terrorists.  We need to equip the community stakeholders to take on a proactive and vigilant role to strengthen our security safety net.

 

     Sir, I wish to ask the Minister the following questions: (1) What are the Ministries multi-pronged approaches to curb self-radicalised terrorists;  (2) What measures are taken to increase community vigilance to prevent self-radicalised terrorism;  (3) How can the Ministry encourage more young people to learn religious teachings from mainstream religious institutions; and (4) How can the Ministry monitor over 6,000 radical religious websites or reduce their influence on young Singaporeans?

Column: 1127

 

Emergency Preparedness

 

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, what more can we do to prepare Singaporeans for major and small emergencies that may arise at home or at public amenities.

 

     I would like to suggest teaching basic first-aid and CPR to as many residents as possible. Are there plans to train female home and caregivers and the elderly; extend the teaching and practice of first-aid to all student groups in schools and consider implementing a short stint of national training for females, where they will learn nursing care?

 

     On the episode of Mas Selamat Kastari, MHA has been very swift to comb him down.  But how else is MHA preparing Singaporeans and other residents on this alert and on emergencies that may arise, especially when there is a possibility that there may be a network operating in the background in Singapore for Mas Selamat to be able to slip away so easily?  How can Singaporeans be prepared for possible pervasive forces?

 

Public Safety and Security

 

     Mr Arthur Fong (West Coast): Sir, on  the subject of public safety and security, MHA has recently announced its plan to extend a network of public security cameras, more than double of what it was previously and in more areas across the island.  Indeed, this is one measure which the MHA has undertaken to promote greater public safety and security. 

 

     Sir, I am pleased to note that the Police has announced a marked drop in crime where CCTVs have been installed, for example, at Boat Quay, Orchard area, Little India, Shenton Way.  According to press reports, footage used from the CCTV has been instrumental in identifying criminals, resulting in breakthrough when solving crimes.  Still, some concerns

Column: 1128

remain.  Adaptable criminals may be able to work around these measures.  Similarly, CCTVs are known to be vandalised.  I hope that the above have been taken into account when expanding the footprint of CCTVs further.

 

     Sir, the use of technology such as CCTVs has broader applications.  Much of the July synchronised bombing in London was recorded by the cameras and this assisted the forensics in unfolding the tactics and unveiling the culprits.

 

     Counter-terrorism at home should be a concern for all Singaporeans and in light of the recent information of Mas Selamat's escape.  This is a concern for all of us.  Terrorists are a different category of fish when compared to the criminals at home.  They are organised, trained and hence a greater threat to our security.  This is the reality that we are faced with. Given this reality, I hope the Minister could oblige us with his view on the role of technology and how it can play to counter terrorism in our front yard.

 

Drug Abuse

 

     Dr Teo Ho Pin: Sir, may I ask the Minister what measures are taken to curb the rise of Subutex and heroin abuse?  Are the barriers to prevent drug trafficking effective at our customs and coastal areas?  What additional measures can be taken to prevent drug trafficking?  Why are sniffer dogs not extensively used to detect drug trafficking at our customs entry points?  How many drug abuse cases were arrested due to ground intelligence or through informants?

 

    Sir, the recent rise in the abuse of Subutex and heroin is a disturbing trend.  We should not accept the reason that the increase is attributed to the implementation of Subutex as a controlled drug.  In fact, it shows weaknesses in our drug enforcement regime.  Our barriers to drug trafficking are not watertight, despite

Column: 1129

Singapore being a small island. Ground intelligence is also insufficient to arrest drug traffickers, pushers and abusers and the surveillance system to track repeat offenders has failed. 

 

     Sir, if big land mass countries like Australia and New Zealand can set up stringent customs and immigration control to prohibit food products being brought into their countries, I do not understand why Singapore cannot set up a more robust customs and immigration control system to curb drug trafficking.  The Australians and New Zealanders use sniffer dogs extensively to deter food and drug trafficking irrespective of religious or racial sensitivities.  We must do likewise and adopt more measures such as deployment of sniffer dogs, scanners and extensive visual checks to strengthen our barriers to drug trafficking.

 

 

     Dr Fatimah Lateef (Marine Parade): Sir, Singapore is known for her strict law pertaining to drug trafficking, distribution and use.  Over the years, there have been effective measures to control the problem, using a multi-pronged as well as community-based approach.  It has attracted much interest from other countries as well.  In fact, in our DRCs now, there are days when we have more visitors than inmates.

 

     In managing the drug abuse problem, besides the individual, physical and psychological consequences related to the addiction, there are also social implications such as family disputes and disruption, non-performance and drop-out from schools, loss of jobs and source of employment.  Over time, the nature and type of drug abuse has also evolved to Subutex, Dormicum, designer as well as lifestyle drugs.  In fact, despite the fact that Subutex has been made a controlled drug, I am still seeing cases coming to the hospital with complications of recent

Column: 1130

abuse.  What are the average numbers of drug related arrests currently?  What are the numbers being entered into our DRCs and what are their ethnic breakdowns?

 

 

     Ms Sylvia Lim (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, last January, Parliament was told that there was no evidence of a Subutex black market and that the majority of Subutex abusers seem to have kicked the habit.  How far has the situation deteriorated last year?  How many Subutex abusers have been arrested for Subutex abuse or abuse of heroin or other drugs?

 

     The recent news of the spike in heroin linked arrests is a cause for concern.  Last year, heroin linked arrests went up by 600% to 670 cases, the highest figure since 2002.  Out of those arrested, 90% were repeat abusers.  The Central Narcotics Bureau said that one of the reasons was the release of 4,000 hardcore addicts from prison over the years.  What does this suggest about the effectiveness of our drug rehabilitation programme and long-term imprisonment as a strategy to fight drug abuse?

 

Public Expression

 

     Ms Eunice Elizabeth Olsen (Nominated Member): Sir, Singapore has come a long way from the time when we were known only for caning vandals and banning chewing gum.  Yes, we are being featured more positively as a city that swings and winning the bid for the Youth Olympic Games will be good for us.  If Singapore wants to be a global city, it must behave like a global city and strive to make it more conducive for a spontaneous and expressive society, not because we want to read more positive stories in the foreign media about Singapore's image, so that Singaporeans can meaningfully identify beyond monetary terms with the notion of belonging to a First World nation.  We can do this by actively nurturing our arts and culture.  We should do this by expanding

Column: 1131

the space for public expression and activity.

 

     Sir, this House heard last year about how the Workers' Party's cycling event was banned and the debate that ensued on political events.  As Nominated MP, I do not propose to join that fray.  I want to take this issue beyond party politics because there is such a wide scope for public expression.  Last year, for example, a group of Singaporeans turned up with anime figurines at a public park to protest against the clamp down on online downloading by Singapore animation distributor, Odex.  The Police sent four anti-riot vans to the scene, took down the anime fans' particulars and filmed them.  It is not an issue of whether we should disapprove of copyright infringement or not.  If the Government wants to rebuke criticisms that Singapore is not a police state, actions like these do not help.  We can all appreciate concerns about law and order.  Race and religion are still sensitive subjects. 

 

    But I wonder if the Home Affairs Ministry can appreciate that there is a wide scope of issues for which more space to public expression can be given.  It is not space for space sake.  We strive to make Singapore a magnet for talent, a top economy, as we should.  But let us not forget what the State does can leave an indelible intangible mark on an educated citizenry.  We are losing about 800 to 1,000 Singaporeans a year.  Would a better balance between law and order and a demonstrable regard for the importance of social expression have made a difference for them, not for all definitely, but for some?  I am sure if every Singaporean counts, it should be enough to warrant relooking how we approach public expression.  We need to learn how to cultivate the value of social expression, in particular by Singaporeans on Singaporean issues, to the benefit of the country.

 

Column: 1132

     I would like to quote from Media Academic Georgian George who wrote on his blog.  He was referring to how Singaporeans have resorted to socially irresponsible expressions on the Internet, and he said, "By failing to enshrine free speech as a fundamental social good, young Singaporeans are growing up seizing that freedom on their own terms impervious to being lectured about their social obligations."  I would like to ask the Minister if he would consider reviewing the Public Entertainments and Meetings Act in Singapore's best interest.

 

Loansharks

 

     Dr Teo Ho Pin: Sir, in Singapore, you can gamble every day.  Mondays and Thursdays are for Toto betting.  Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays are for 4-D betting.  Horse racing is on every Saturday and Sunday.  Big Sweep, you can bet once a month.  And soccer betting is available almost everyday, depending on the matches.  If you miss all of the above, you can still take a cruise to nowhere and gamble at a casino any day.  So the high accessibility has created a new industry in Singapore, that is, illegal moneylending or loanshark services. 

 

     In recent years, we have seen a first in loanshark harassment cases.  On average, about 4,000 to 5,000 households were harassed by loansharks yearly.  This rampant loanshark activity has affected the safety of our residents and their quality of life.

 

     Sir, Singaporeans are aware of the moneylending and debt collection tactics of loansharks and yet many have resorted to borrowing money from loansharks.  Why is it so?  It is due to gambling.  I foresee this problem will be further aggravated when the two Integrated Resorts are operational.  The Police must take immediate concrete action to curb loanshark activities.  May I ask the Minister why is there a sudden increase in

Column: 1133

loanshark activities?  How many reported loanshark cases were resolved by the Police?  What are the strategies or measures to prevent loanshark activities in Singapore?  What are the education efforts by Police on loansharks?  Are these efforts effective in educating Singaporeans not to borrow from loansharks?

 

 

 

12.15 pm

 

     Mr Arthur Fong : Sir, the issue of loansharks or illegal moneylending is not only a menace to society but it is also posing a present and direct challenge to the authorities.  Reports of harassments have been widely covered in the media.  Of concern are the innocent victims of such harassments.  Most of us, if not all of us, in this House would have encountered at some time or other during our meet-the-people sessions of residents telling us the problem they face from harassment from loansharks.  Woe befalls anyone who had bought a resale flat whose previous owner had borrowed money from these loansharks.  If the previous owner had outstanding debts, the loansharks' runners are indifferent to whether the new owners have anything to do with the previous occupant.  Spray painting on the walls is a form of vandalism, and some even had the gall to cut off the electricity supply of "lenders".  Some have even resorted to harassing neighbours or occupants of those flats to embarrass them into paying. 

 

     I spoke with a Singapore PR who came from Hong Kong.  I asked him, "Do you have this problem in Hong Kong?"  He said, "Oh, maybe the Hong Kong loansharks are more kiasu than the Singapore ones."  I asked him, "Why do you say that?"  He said that when the loansharks lend them the money, they actually do due diligence.  I asked him what he meant.  He said they went to

Column: 1134

verify where they live so that they would not have these innocent parties suffering.  I do not know.  It is quite laughable.  But to these residents who come to see us at our MPS, it is not funny at all. 

 

     While I am glad that the Government has gone out in the media to show the plight, pain and suffering of gambling addicts' families in the effort to bring awareness to our people, the other end of the gambling problem, ie, that of the loansharks, is still very much in our midst.  As long as there are borrowers, loansharks and their illegal moneylending activities will exist.  However, their debt recovery methods have caused much stress, fear and tension not only to the occupants of the targeted flats but to the neighbours as well.  I ask for a stronger enforcement and whether the current law is adequate enough to deal with this menace.

 

Borrowing Money from Unlicensed Moneylenders

 

     Mr Christopher de Souza (Holland-Bukit Timah): "Owe money, pay money" - these threatening words mar the walls of several common corridors of our HDB homes. 

 

     In January last year, Senior Minister of State, Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee, informed that there were 10,221 reported cases of unlicensed moneylending in 2006.  That was a 19% increase over 2005 when there were 8,568 reported cases.  Similarly, the 2005 figure represented an increase of 47%, to be exact, over 2004, which had 5,809 reported cases.  Multiple initiatives were introduced by MHA to try to solve the problem.  These included:

 

     (a)  Enhancing the penalties under the Moneylenders' Act; and

 

     (b)  The formation of the Anti-UML Task Force to increase, among others, the number of ambush operations.

 

Column: 1135

     However, recent figures show that these measures have not deterred UML syndicates.  A look at the statistics for 2007 support this point.  In 2007, there were 277 arrests over the first three quarters, ie, from January to September, which were just 17 short of the total number of arrests for the whole of 2006.  All else being equal, working from an average of 30 cases per month, the total figure for 2007 would be in the region of about 360.  In the same nine months in 2007, there were 7,438 reported cases of illegal moneylending and related activities.  All else being equal, working from an average of 826 cases per month, the total figure for 2007 would be in the region of 9,917 cases.  This is a mere drop of about 300 reported cases from 2006-07.  Having previously worked with enforcement agencies to tackle similar types of crime, I put on record my appreciation for their dedicated effort in their attempt to deter UML activities in Singapore. 

 

     However, in the light of the unattractive figures quoted above, I urge MHA to take a different strategy in tackling the very real problem of unlicensed moneylending.  This involves simultaneously tackling the supply of and the demand for illegal loans.  Currently, the law, called the Moneylenders Act, curbs UML only by deterring the supply of illegal loans into the market.  It does nothing to penalise or deter the borrowing, ie, the demand side.  This is clear from sections 8(1)(b) and (c) of the Moneylenders Act.  These offences in these sections do not deter the demand for illegal loans.  I therefore propose that MHA consider introducing a new section which makes it an offence if a person secures a loan for himself or on behalf of any other person from an unlicensed moneylender.  The punitive measures which come along with the offence can be calculated based on the harm that the State deems such borrowing creates and based on the level that will best deter such activities.  Naturally, the Public

Column: 1136

Prosecutor will have the ultimate discretion whether to prosecute a borrower, and unique circumstances prompting a compassionate approach would likely merit non-prosecution.

 

     Having said this, the merit of making borrowing illegal and having it in the books, as it were, is that it deters people from taking loans which cause both them and their neighbours a great deal of distress.  Taking a page out of the speeches of Dr Teo Ho Pin and Mr Arthur Fong, to my mind, a good example, though not the only example, of a borrower who deserves to be prosecuted is one who gives a false address to the loansharks such that innocent residents get harassed.  If the borrower abets such harassment, why not make his very act of borrowing an offence? 

 

     There are two prominent pieces of legislation which combat both the supply and demand elements of an offence. 

 

     The first is the Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA).  Sections 5, 6 and 7 of the MDA penalise the trafficking, import and export and manufacture of controlled drugs, ie, the supply of them.  But, significantly, section 8 of the MDA also penalises the possession and consumption of controlled drugs, ie, the demand for them.  By penalising both the demand and supply, Singapore's drug problem has been contained. 

 

     The second prominent piece of legislation is the Prevention of Corruption Act (PCA).  Section 5(a) of the PCA penalises the supply of corruption, ie, it

Column: 1137

penalises, subject to other elements being satisfied, the corrupt soliciting or receiving or agreeing to receive for himself or for any other person any gratification as an inducement to or reward for.  In order to effectively deter acts of corruption in Singapore, section 5(b) of the PCA penalises the demand for corruption, ie, it penalises, subject to other elements being satisfied, the corrupt giving, promising or offering to any person, whether for the benefit of that person or of any other person any gratification as an inducement or reward for. 

 

     Thus, both the demand and supply of elements of corruption are tackled in tandem, resulting in Singapore's extremely low incidence of corruption.  Why not use the same strategy to combat the rapid growth of unlicensed moneylending in Singapore, given that:

 

     (a)  The anecdotal evidence that a significant number of those borrowing from loansharks are using the loan to pay off gambling debts?

 

     (b)  As a result, innocent residents have to bear the brunt of harassment if a false residential address is given?

 

     (c)  The whole corridor suffers the stigma of graffitied walls even if a false address is not given?

 

     (d)  The continuing Government philosophy that if we continue to work, we will be given an incentive, such as WIS, why not make borrowing from illegal moneylenders, which causes much harm to the neighbourliness of communities, an offence?

 

     The Public Prosecutor is always in a position to exercise his discretion whether or not to prosecute the borrower based on the unique mitigating factors, if any.  The number of reported cases and arrests in relation to unlicensed moneylending and related activities over the last three years is very worrying.  I urge MHA to consider a shift in policy away from supply-centric enforcement to one which also combats the demand.  This would be similar to the two-pronged enforcement action taken against drugs and corruption.  Such a

Column: 1138

two-pronged strategy focusing on the supply and demand forces giving rise to the crime would pressure the offence from all sides and help lead it closer to extinction. 

 

     I propose that MHA use a portion of its budget to analyse how a new provision can be introduced into the Moneylenders Act to make the borrowing of money from unlicensed moneylenders an offence. 

 

     Turning, Sir, to my second cut.

 

To Clamp Down on Prostitution and Associated Vices

 

     The number of foreign prostitutes arrested in 2006 was 4,310.  This was a 34% increase over 2005.  In 2007, the number of foreign prostitutes arrested was 5,400.  This signified a 25% increase over 2006.  Bids to contain the trade in Geylang has not been successful.  An evening drive down Duxton Road and Duxton Hill - which I did with my wife by the way - will prove that prostitutes operate well beyond the artificial borders of Geylang.  Prostitution is working itself into our heartlands.  Many of these sex workers come on two-week social visit passes.  Just before the two weeks come to an end, the sex workers leave the country, usually by making their way to JB, only to return to Singapore the same day.  This trip, which earns them an extended stay in Singapore, is known as the "U-turn".  Many of them continue to ply the trade until caught for overstaying.  I am told that they even get a free ticket home when repatriated after serving their jail sentences. 

 

     We have all seen several reports in the press of prostitutes openly soliciting in coffeeshops.  I have also received feedback that sexual services are offered at shops claiming to offer massages, especially, for some reason, massage parlours with curtains.  The numbers speak for themselves: 34% rise in number of foreign prostitutes arrested from 2005 to

Column: 1139

2006, 25% rise from 2006 to 2007.  What concrete steps will MHA take to curb the worrying figures?  In particular, would MHA allocate a healthy budget to bolster the anti-vice squad with additional manpower and intelligence officers to:

 

     (a)  Suss out new locations where sex syndicates operate?

 

     (b)  Clamp down on such operations?

 

Road Safety

 

     Dr Teo Ho Pin: Sir, may I ask the Minister:

 

     (1)  What measures are in place to ensure that road safety is properly taught in driving schools?

 

     (2)  Are the existing road safety and courtesy programmes effective in improving drivers' driving behaviour and reducing accidents?
